text: Thanks for the advice! Got a few contacts out it!
Also, what are you thoughts on the question you asked me about mid generational upgrades?
I can't find the video at the moment, but Spawn Wave did a really good video how he thinks console development is changing, especially with Microsoft and Sony.

Oh cool, I'll try and find it and give it a listen.
It's a weird one, because I started out with consoles like mega drive and n64 but I turned into a pc gamer, so for me, upgrading after a few years is always a given. It's interesting when consoles do them and I think it's cool to push the tech forwards but you'll always be "stuck" with the previous tech, because you don't want to alienate the consumers who own the first version of your console.
Say for instance Bloodborne, they didn't make a performance patch for the ps4 pro to 60fps because it would give the players a tactical advantage in pvp over the people on just a ps4. If they started modularly designing consoles to be upgradable, that might be smarter, although that hasn't really worked out financially in the past.
Since this was the first generation this happened, I think it will improve from here, companies will find smarter ways to do it
And tell me more about the talks and networking session, what did you learn from the talks and who did you end up meeting?
I met Gary Napper, who talked about his exprecente while doing game jams, Jupiter Hadley, someone who I interviewed and Gareth Qually, a graphic artist who is learning about game development.
awesome, thats really cool. Did you get any insights into what you'd like to focus on?
However, what really liked was the first talk on Deconstructing Super Mario Bros.
That sounds great, how was It broken down?
He went through level 1-1 and how everything was split into different screens.
Also, how do you do faceal animation? That seems to be the thing I'm struggling with the most at the moment.
